title: glasgow-go-quot-bankrupt-quot-250m-new-equal-pay-claims
story: Gary Smith, who leads the GMB in Scotland, said a fresh round of claims would be submitted by female workers months after an initial poundm settlement was secured.He said he feared Glasgow could become like a US city that famously went bust: "It could be Detroit without the soundtrack."However, SNP council leader Susan Aitken hit back yesterday: ldquoThese are nonsense figures, plucked from thin air ndash and it is worth remembering that pretty much every single prediction anyone has ever made about this has been wrong."Earlier this year, the city council appeared to end a long-running dispute with thousands of female staff who had been paid less than men on the same grade.The council challenged the claims for years before the incoming SNP administration changed tacked and settled.The local authorityrsquos strategy for meeting the poundm bill was for a council spin-off firm to take a loan out against the cityrsquos publicly-owned buildings. Women are in line for an average payment of pound,.However, the disputed pay structure is still in place and the GMB, which represents many of the staff, is helping female workers put in a new wave of claims.Smithrsquos GMB union was criticised in previous years for not doing enough to help the female workers, but his appointment in  led to a rethink and his colleagues have since vigorously represented the women.Speaking to the Herald on Sunday, Smith said the poundm may only be the beginning for the council:ldquoThe women are still being discriminated against in Glasgow because there is not a new pay and grading structure in place. For every second these women are at work they are losing out.ldquoAs new people are employed by the council, as soon as they start, many of them are going to have claims against the council as well. The council is paying out pound-plus million, and it is immediately racking up the credit card bill again.He put a figure on what the new bill may come to: ldquoBy  the city council will need to find at least another pound million to fully settle its historic sex discrimination against its employees and it will need to implement a new job evaluation system to address that discrimination once and for all.Smith is worried that Glasgow may fail to pay its bills: ldquoI donrsquot know, in real terms,cities can go bankrupt in the UK, but to all intents and purposes Glasgow is going to run out of money. If you want to call that bankruptcy, fine."At some point, the Scottish Government is going to have to step in. You cannot keep remortgaging all the buildings in Glasgow. You canrsquot keep cutting services."ldquoThere is a precedent for cities going bust where in the world. I donrsquot think you can let Scotlandrsquos biggest city go bankrupt, but something has got to be done to reverse the decline of Glasgow and, once and for all, sort out the debts.The SNP currently runs the council, but Smith says the political blame predates Nationalist control: ldquoYou have got an administration now that is dealing with generations of mismanagement. You cannot heap all the blame on the current political administration, but there is no easy way out of this.However, he is angry that council officials who he regards as responsible for past mistakes are still in post.ldquoOn the face of it, it feels like the people who were there when we got into this mess are still there now. And that is pretty staggering, he said.Aitken added: ldquoUntil we implement a new pay scheme, there will be further equal pay claims to settle. Everybody knows that ndash it was in the paper we took to committee. We are factoring this into our funding strategy. However, the claims will be smaller in number and they will also cover a far shorter period.

title: science-fiction-become-science-fact
story: Itrsquos the th anniversary of George Orwellrsquos Nineteen Eighty-Four ndash a book which predicted so much of the darker side of modern le. Here Writer at Large Neil Mackay looks at how science fiction has often become science factBIG Brother, thoughtcrime, Newspeak, the two minutes hate. When George Orwellrsquos Nineteen Eighty-Four was published  years ago this summer his terrying fictional vision of a totalitarian future was just that ndash fiction. Today, though, the book, which Orwell wrote in the last months of his le on the Isle of Jura, has become frighteningly true.Orwell was able to predict with chilling prescience the future in which we now live ndash just as so many writers and film-makers have, from EM Forster foretelling the internet to Star Trek envisioning mobile phones. Once a writer imagines the future, itrsquos not long before scientists, politicians or society at large turns it into a reality.Big Brother and ... the telescreenOrwellrsquos most chillingly accurate prophesy was the telescreen ndash a combined TV, security camera and listening device in the home of every citizen. From CCTV and facial recognition technology to the Alexa Amazon device and big data, modern society has accepted almost unquestioningly the right of the state to observe us and companies to harvest information about us. Itrsquos hardly surprising that one of the most popular reality TV shows called itself Big Brother ndash and pandered to our voyeuristic desire to watch and control others.Big Brother was, of course, the dictator who ran the Britain of Nineteen Eighty-Four ndash where poster warned ldquoBig Brother is Watching You.The two minutes hate and thoughtcrimeEvery day, citizens in the novel Nineteen Eighty-Four gather to unleash two minutes of hate against perceived enemies of the state who have committed the offence of thoughtcrime ndash of thinking ideas they should not have been thinking. Offenders are rounded up by the thought police.It sounds very like a social media storm where unlucky victims are pilloried for daring to say something deemed offensive. Think of the actor Matt Damon who said this during the height of the MeToo movement: ldquoTherersquos a dference between patting someone on the butt and rape or child molestation. Both of those behaviours need to be confronted and eradicated without question, but they shouldnrsquot be conflated. His words, though true, were subject to outrage.NewspeakIn , language is twisted and manipulated by the state to control the people. So a concentration camp becomes a ldquojoycamp, the Ministry of Truth is really the Ministry of Propaganda. Politicians today use their own form of Newspeak to befuddle the people and twist reality ndash think of phrases like ldquocollateral damage to describe civilian casualties of war.The Machine Stops and ... the internetThe Machine Stops was written by EM Forster in . In the tale, obese humans live underground dependent on ldquothe machine ndash which provides for all needs and entertainment. Humans speak to each other via a kind of text messaging and internet service within the machine.Humans barely move or interact ndash no-one cares about the natural world. In the end, the machine stops and what passes for ldquocivilisation stops with it.Minority Report and ... personalised advertsYou know how creepy it is when yoursquove browsed some book online and then adverts for the same product pop up everywhere you look on the web  Welcome to Minority Report.In the  film, inspired by a Philip K Dick story, technology has advanced so far that it can predict crimes yet to be committed. Businesses can scan a personrsquos mind and display bespoke adverts on billboards just for them. Today, General Motors has already created billboards that change according to the car you are driving.Minority Report also saw Tom Cruise using touch screens ndash pinching, pulling and swiping ndash long before such technology was a reality.Star Trek and ... pretty much everythingldquoEnterprise, this is Captain Kirk, come in Enterprise.On Star Trek, crew members have a communicator ndash a clever little gizmo that fits snuggly in your hand and lets you talk to anyone, anywhere. Itrsquos also a GPS device. Pretty much your prototype mobile phone in the s. Star Trek also had a ldquoreplicator ndash technology that could build anything you wanted. In effect, creator Gene Roddenberry was predicting the D printer.If thatrsquos not enough future predictions, Star Trek also imagined the iPad. Programme-makers even called it a PADD or personal access display device. Creepily prescient. Other predictions in Star Trek include Bluetooth ndash remember Uhurursquos big earpiece  ndash Google Glasses and virtual medical diagnoses.Blade Runner and ... the rise of ChinaThe Los Angeles of the future seen in Ridley Scottrsquos  movie looks like a Chinese supercity of today ndash ironically, the film was set in the year . In the movie, Chinese and Asian culture is on the rise. Adverts feature Chinese goods and celebrities . LA residents speak a mix of English and Asian languages. Today, Mandarin is predicted by many linguists to overtake English as the international language one day.Blade Runner, like a number of other movies including Total Recall, also envisions a future where space has been privatised. Companies like Elon Muskrsquos SpaceX are currently trying to carve up the cosmos for corporations ndash something which would have horried Philip K Dick, who wrote the short story Do Androids Dream Of Electric Sheep  which inspired the movie.AI and ... robotsSteven Spielbergrsquos  futuristic fairytale AI delves into a world populated by androids, almost indistinguishable from humans. In AI, robots are used to serve humanityrsquos baser instincts. They are killed for sport, and exploited for sex. Current inventions such as the sex robot took Spielbergrsquos dark fictional vision and turned it into fact.Robots first appeared in the acclaimed Czech play Rossumrsquos Universal Robots by Karel Capek. The play captures all the concerns we still have today about robotics and AI. At first, Capekrsquos robots are happy slaves, but they rebel and destroy the human race. Today, scientists debate the threat of the ldquosingularity ndash when robot intelligence surpasses human intelligence and humanity risks being sidelined or even eliminated, as Stephen Hawking warned. Think Arnold Schwarzenegger and Terminator and you get the picture.The Handmaidrsquos Tale and ... womenrsquos rightsWe once thought of Margaret Atwoodrsquos acclaimed  dystopian novel as a warning of a future that may come to pass, not a prophesy of a future that would come to pass. However, the assaults on womenrsquos rights around the world feel more like The Handmaidrsquos Tale every day.Just a week ago, an Alabama woman faced criminal charges after being shot and losing her baby. Ohio wants to effectively ban nearly all abortions. In The Handmaidrsquos Tale, religious extremists run rampant across America, calling the shots. Today, fundamentalists in the USA have never before had so much clout.Brave New World and ... medicineIn Aldous Huxleyrsquos  novel Brave New World, the drug Soma is used to keep the population calm and happy. Today, some four million people in the UK are long-term users of anti-depressants.Huxley also imagined a future where embryos are cloned and genetically modied ndash a prophecy of our ethical concerns today, including the danger of ldquodesigner babies following the decoding of the human genome. When the clone Dolly the Sheep was ldquoinvented in Scotland many spoke of the coming of a ldquoBrave New World.The book also envisions a world where movies have become ldquofeelies ndash with the audience physically immersed in the film. With the coming of virtual reality, ldquogoing to the feelies may soon be a common phrase.The Running Man and ... reality TVBased on a Stephen King story, the film The Running Man sees Arnie forced to compete in a reality TV show where he is hunted and faced with being killed for the entertainment of viewers. We havenrsquot quite got there yet, but the excesses of reality TV where unimaginable back in .Today, wersquove got reality shows such as Naked and Afraid which sees contestants stranded stark naked in the rainforest, surrounded by predators, and left to survive with nothing but a kne and a fire-starter. The extreme emotional and mental humiliation heaped on contestants in other shows like Big Brother is also, self-evidently, a cruel sport meant to entertain us.The Six Million Dollar Man and ... bionicsldquoSteve Austin, astronaut. A man barely alive. Gentlemen, we can rebuild him. We have the technology. We have the capability to build the worldrsquos first bionic man. Steve Austin will be that man. Better than he was before. Better, stronger, faster.So went the famous opening monologue in the s series The Six Million Dollar Man, which starred Lee Majors. The show was based on the book Cyborg by Martin Caidin. Austin was horribly injured and given a robotic eye and arm, and bionic legs.Today, prosthetic, robotised limbs are no longer the stuff of science fiction and have changed the lives of those who have suffered le-altering injuries.Snow Crash and ... Second LeNovelist Neal Stephenson imagined what he called a ldquometaverse in his  novel Snow Crash ndash where people lived inside a computer-simulated world as ldquoavatars of themselves. In , there were more than one million people living in the world of Second Le ndash an online universe where player-citizens could buy imaginary clothes, rent imaginary land and build imaginary homes. Reuters had its own reporter in Second Le. People married in Second Le ndash real relationships were broken up because of ldquocyber-affairs in Second Le. Sweden even opened an embassy in Second Le.District  and ... immigrationThe film District  is a parable of xenophobia and racism which tells the story of an alien spaceship stranded in South Africa. The insect-like alien refugees are consigned to camps and treated as a sub-species. When the film was made in  it was seen as harking back to the worst excesses of the th century and a warning to the future for mistakes not to be repeated.As we can see from the migrant crisis on the southern border of the United States, where families are being locked up in what opponents have termed ldquoconcentration camps, some warnings are never heeded.Iron Man and ... military hardwareIron Man has been fighting baddies in his exoskeleton bodysuit since  ndash but the US military is fast catching up with him. The United States Special Operations Command should begin testing its Talos suit any time now. Talos, or Tactical Assault Light Operator Suit, is a robotic exoskeleton thatrsquos bulletproof, weaponised, gives the wearer additional strength and perception, and monitors all vital signs.Like drones, which have featured in numerous sci-fi outings such as the infamous Sentinels in The Matrix, exosuits are just the latest fiction to be made fact by the military. HG Wells imagined giant metal war machines crawling across the land in his  story The Land Ironclads. Just over a decade later, the tank was fighting on the frontlines of the western front in the First World War.Jules Verne and ... space travelIn , Jules Vernersquos From The Earth To The Moon, imagined a manned landing on the lunar surface. In , HG Wells reprised the idea in The First Men In The Moon. Both writers were way off the mark in terms of the science that eventually got us there, and what awaited us when we arrived, but they were right in predicting that one day humans would walk on the Moon.Today, our fiction is brimful of sci-fi writers imagining the le that awaits us on Mars. From the movie The Martian to the docu-drama series Mars, it seems the human imagination has never been so fixated on the idea of stepping foot on to the Red Planet.There are plans for a US mission to Mars sometime around  ndash so within  years we could see yet another idea which first began with a prediction on the page or on the screen becoming a reality.Star Wars and ... the hologramldquoHelp me, Obi-Wan Kenobi. Yoursquore my only hope.The words of Princess Leia in hologram form in one of the most famous scenes in the  film Star Wars. Today, holograms are prohibitively expensive but very real. In , a hologram of Tupac Shakur appeared onstage rapping beside Snoop Dog ndash Shakur had been dead for  years.Idiocracy and ... social mediaThe  satire Idiocracy imagines a future world where everyone is as thick as two short planks. If you wanted a prediction of what the world would look like after the invention of social media and its possible worst effects, this is it.Other future visions which came trueThe cartoon The Jetsons predicted the smartwatch in .Videophones appear in the  movie polis.The credit card ndash which took off in the s ndash was predicted in the  novel Looking Backward.Ray Bradbury predicted earbud headphones in Fahrenheit  ndash he refers to them as like "seashells" or "thimble radios".And who can forget KITT, the driverless car from Knight Rider, starring David Hasselhoff ndash first imagined back in .

title: operation-unicorn-secret-strategy-queen-dying-scotland
story: Operation Unicorn will involve the immediate suspension of business at the Scottish Parliament as the authorities prepare for a state funeral that will become a global event.A Holyrood source said the Queen dying north of the border could result in hundreds of thousands of people from across the world flocking to Holyrood.It has previously been reported that the UK strategy for handling the Queenrsquos death, Operation London Bridge, dates back to the s.The plan has been adapted since the turn of the century and it is believed meetings take place around three times a year that include government departments, the police and broadcasters.However, an online minute of the Scottish Parliamentrsquos Leadership Group , a forum for senior Holyrood staff, revealed the existence of a parallel strategy.The account of the meeting, which took place in June, stated: ldquoLG received an update on planning for Operation Unicorn ndash the death of Her Majesty The Queen while in Scotland. The primary focus was on the impacts on staffing and the specic impacts depending on timing.The secret codename was first mentioned in the Parliamentrsquos online papers in  when LG agreed to set up a ldquoresilience board for ldquodisruptive incidents.Parliament proposed that the ldquosignicant incidents should include Holyroods role in London Bridge and Unicorn, without specying what the latter meant.It is understood thatthe Queen dies in Scotland - she spends around three months a year at Balmoral - the Parliament, the neighbouring Palace of Holyroodhouse, and St Gilesrsquo Cathedral will be the main focal points.If the Monarch dies when the Parliament is sitting, chamber and committee business will be suspended and the funeral will take place around ten days after her death.It is believed that up to six parliamentary days could be lost, but there will be thirty six hours to prepare for a motion of condolence in the chamber.One of the major challenges facing the Parliament is coping with the huge number of people who are expected to want to sign a condolence book at Holyrood.If the Queen passes away in Scotland, her body will rest at Holyroodhouse, following which her coffin will be carried to the cathedral on the Royal Mile.At this point, her body will be placed on the Royal Train at Waverley station for a journey down the east coast mainline.Passing references have been made to Operation Unicorn in NHS board papers, but with no explanation for what it is.Transport for Edinburgh , which manages the Capitalrsquos bus and tram network, is expected to have an important role in the days after the Queenrsquos death.According to a TfL report, the transport body was last year given delegated authority for the coordination of the Edinburgh council side of Unicorn and other sensitive operations.It noted that TfL had secured ldquolong term resources for these tasks, including police and army personnel, as well as ldquopro bono support from a firm called Inverroy Crisis Management.A newspaper reported last year that civic leaders in Scotland had taken part in a summit on Operation London Bridge.ldquoIt was a provostrsquos association meeting, one participant was quoted saying. ldquoWe were getting briefed on a very sensitive issue that we canrsquot say anything about. We meet every so often.A Scottish Parliament spokesperson said: "The existence of plans for a future change of reign are a matter of public record."

title: filthy-glasgow-political-economic-decline-says-trade-union-leader
story: In a blistering attack on the state of Scotlandrsquos largest city, GMB Scotland boss Gary Smith also derided the quality of the local airport and said Glasgow is suffering from an ldquoepidemic of rats.He added: ldquoGlasgow is teetering on the brink of crisis.In common with local authorities across Scotland, Glasgow council has endured a tight squeeze on public spending for nearly a decade.The UK Governmentrsquos austerity agenda has put pressure on Holyroodrsquos budget, but the SNP Government also stands accused of passing on cuts to local government.Figures from the Parliament show that the councilrsquos revenue funding per head dropped by pound between   to  .Thousands of local authority job losses have slashed costs and services have been cut. An equal pay dispute, which pre-dates the years of austerity, also placed additional burdens on budgets, and thoroughfares such as Sauchiehall Street and Argyll Street are regarded as eyesores.It was also reported that , rat infestation complaints had been made and last week it emerged that Glasgowrsquos homes had been visited more than , times by pest control staff over the past  months.However, the councilrsquos defenders say that the cityrsquos educational outcomes are healthy and that many of the local authoritys outcomes are positive.Smith, whose union represents thousands of council staff, is a critic of the way the city has been run over the years.Labour, to which his trade union is affiliated, ran the local authority for decades, but was dumped from office by the Nationalists in .The union leader, who moved back to Scotland after living and working in the south of England, lashed out at what he regards as Glasgowrsquos crumbling public sphere.He said: ldquoIt feels like a city that is in decline. Wersquove got public buildings in a state of decay - the Mitchell Library, the problems with the Peoplersquos Palace - the streets are absolutely filthy and wersquove got an epidemic of rats in large parts of the city.ldquoToo often the politicians are happy to hide behind this bluff and bluster about lsquopeople make Glasgowrsquo. The people of Glasgow deserve better than they are getting.Smith blasted a combination of public spending cuts and ldquobackdoor privatisation, saying: ldquoAll of this leaves the city in a state that feels unkempt, unloved and, in a lot of areas, actually really filthy.Askedhe believed Glasgow is going backwards, he said: ldquoYes, definitely. It is a city that is in economic and political decline. It feels as though the power and wealth is increasingly centred in Edinburgh, which is like a mini-London.The Herald on Sunday last month reported Scotlandrsquos changing demographics, which are expected to see families leaving areas such as Inverclyde and Ayrshire for locations such as Edinburgh and the wider Lothians. The capital is in line to enjoy a , population boom, more than Glasgow.Smith said the creation of the Parliament was supposed to help Glasgow, but claimed the reality had been dferent:ldquoOne of the fundamental reasons why devolution is not delivering is that it was supposed to rebalance the economy. I donrsquot see any evidence that that is happening, particularly in the west coast of Scotland.He added: ldquoThere is no way the Scottish Government can keep burying its head in the sand with the state and the decline of Glasgow.Scottish Tory MSP Annie Wells said: ldquoTherersquos no doubt that this SNP council administration is badly letting down Glasgow. Under them we have seen problems across the city go unaddressed, especially concerning the growth of rats and uncollected waste. Meanwhile SNP councillors would prefer to spend their time talking about independence rather than tackling these serious issues.Susan Aitken, the SNP leader of Glasgow council, said: ldquoContrary to what Mr Smith says, GMB members are doing a great job for Glasgow. Any big city faces challenges with waste and litter, but we are investing in our services ndash including taking on additional staff.

title: snp-mp-joanna-cherry-qc-made-citizens-assembly-39-ten-times-harder-39-says-adviser
story: Dr Oliver Escobar suggestedthecomment by Joanna Cherry QC last week wasso unhelpful it had made the forumswork ldquoten times harder.He told the Herald such commentsmade it harder becauseunderstanding of the Assembly was still in its infancy and it had yet to gain public trust.That meant people might not distinguish between Ms Cherry speaking as a politician with onepoint of view, and the entirely separate, independentorganisationofthe Assembly.Announced by Nicola Sturgeon in April as a way of thrashing out the long-term challenges facing Scotland, the Assembly has been dogged by claims it is a Nationalist front.Based on the Irish models which led to referendums legalising same-sex marriage and abortion, the Assembly will recruit its first  members and  substitutes over the summer, then deliberate over six weekends from later October to late April.In Ireland, cross-party buy-in and independence were vital factors in the exercisersquos success.However the Scottish Tories and Scottish LibDems have already said they will have nothing to do with the Scottish version, with Unionist campaigners urging a boycott.Last week its first co-convener David Martin, the former Scottish Labour MEP, appealed for cooperation and insisted the forum would be independent from the SNP Government.However a day later Ms Cherry, the SNPrsquos justice spokeswoman at Westminster, fuelled Unionist suspicions by saying the Assembly was part of a wider independence effort.In an online video, she described it as ldquothe perfect way to move Scotland on from the current state of Brexit paralysis created by westminster and to move us towards independence.:SNP MP Joanna Cherry QC says Citizens Assembly is perfect way to advance independenceHer Twitter post was advertising an Electoral Reform Society event at Edinburgh University tomorrow about the Assembly in which she and Dr Escobar will participate.Dr Escobar, an expert in public policy at the Edinburgh, has advised SNP Brexit Secretary Michael Russell on the importance of ldquobuilding cross-party support for the Assembly.Also expected to be the lead researcher on the body, he told Scotland and Sunday that Ms Cherryrsquos comment was ldquocompletely against the ethos of such assembles.ldquoIm kind of fuming around that, adding an open-minded and unbiased approach was the "fundamental underpinning of the legitimacy of this body.He said: "I wouldnt be involved in advising, and hopefully soon to be confirmed in doing research around this,I believed that this was an already forgone conclusion."So earlier this week, when comments were made by a very prominent member of the SNP, it was perhaps the most unhelpful contribution that has been made so far to this process.ldquoI understand why this happens - it happens because theyre talking to their own supporters, they frame it in a way that is appealing to them. But it completely goes against the ethos."The person who made these comments has actually nothing to do with the Citizens Assembly. Shes not involved in organising it, shes not involved in any of the advisory boards. Shes just someone who has advocated for Citizens Assemblies because shes been inspired by the Irish example."Professor David Farrell of University College Dublin, research director on the first Irish assembly, also told the paper that perceived bias was ldquoa serious risk to the new project.He said: ldquoI think theres a serious riskthere isnt some buy-in from most of the parties that it could undermine it. Thats a serious risk."In both of the Irish processes, pretty much all of the parties were able to buy in - and in some cases quite reluctantly in the beginning. But I think that was so important.ldquoYou can see it with social media commentary already that there are people who are seeing this as a stitchup which is what you get early on. The best way to reduce that criticism is to say Look, we have some buy-in from all parties."We had much the same when we were talking about abortion because that would have been similarly an extremely controversial topic."So whats really important is that its seen to be independent, objective, fully transparent.":Citizens Assembly hit by recruitment delay amid Unionist calls for boycottDr Escobar told the Herald: ldquoWhat I really want to highlight is that there is a distinction, and itrsquos an important distinction, between public leaders like Joanna, who are advocates and supporters for this kind of methodology for involving the public, versus those who are actually impartial organisers who will have the responsibility to deliver this important process, and shersquos not part of that."I donrsquot think that thatrsquos a distinction that has been made properly.ldquoItrsquos all coming out as an attack on Joanna. To be honest, you know, these things very rarely get visibility, these kind of alternative forums of democractic engagement.ldquoTherefore it is important that leaders like Joanna and others come into that space and speak to their own supporters, which I think is what Joanna was saying when she said she was hopeful this is going to help the path to independence.ldquoBut the problem is that there is a public perception that this is just an SNP thing. But actually the Assembly is going to be independent from government.ldquoItrsquos important we are not mixing those who are advocates and public leaders who are calling for this, because they hope itrsquos going to help in their own cause, but that is not necessarily the agenda of the assembly, and certainly the organisers are a dferent sort of group.He went on: ldquoI do think that comments like that, because there is no public perception of the distinction between Joanna and the people actually involved in developing the Assembly, I think itrsquos true that these comments at this stage can make things much harder for people to really find some legitimate ground the Assembly to do its work properlywith public trust.ldquoBut, Joanna, you know, in that sense I donrsquot regret saying that. It does make it harder, until it will begin to distinguish between those who are speaking about the Assembly and calling for it, and those who are actually going to deliver an impartial process.Askedhe was concerned he had been misquoted, he said: "Speaking to the Scotsman I never mentioned Joannarsquos name, but obviously it was between the lines."I did say last week there were unhelpful comments that are making things ten times harder because we are not yet at the stage [of]a mature public conversation about what the Assembly could accomplishgiven the chance.ldquoIt just comes across as very personal, but then again Irsquom not that naive not to understand how things come out.ldquoUnless the Assembly has the trust of everyone across the ideological spectrum then itrsquos not going to work. Itrsquos important that people like Joanne speak up, but itrsquos just about understanding that shersquos not speaking up for ious assemblies, shersquos speaking up from her elected politician position and public leader position rather than anything to do with the actual delivery of the Assembly."I welcome contributions from politicians, but itrsquos just about how they choose to frame it.In a series of tweets this morning, Ms Cherry said she stood by her comment, and said it was part of the ldquojoy of democracy that others might disagree.However she also called for people to approach the Assembly with an ldquoopen mind.A short positive thread on #CitizensAssemblies #She told the Herald: "Of course Irsquom always interested in independence. Thatrsquos hardly a revelation. But the Citizens Assembly is about looking at policy issues which interest everyone regardless of their stance on Independence. The remit at present is wide."There are all sorts of future challenges the assembly could look at. Having pioneered this exciting initiative it would be surprisingI wanted to undermine it and I donrsquot."If there is a threat to the integrity of the CitizensAssembly it comes from those boycotting it andmisrepresenting its purpose. So I fully endorse David Martinrsquos call to those planning a boycott to think again."

title: POLITICS WATCH   Shadow Chancellor rubbishes talk of Labour splits
story: On the political talk shows yesterday, that principle was turned on its head with Labour keen to do a Garbo and the Conservatives positively giddy with talk of the future.The weekend newspapers had decided that the outcome of the race to lead the Conservatives, and the UK, was all but over bar the shouting, and television producers agreed. It was time to look ahead to what an administration led by Boris Johnson might look like, and what it would do. Interviews for positions have been open for quite some time now, but it is never too late to remind an incoming Prime Minister of onersquos worth as a television performer.Dominic Raab, former Brexit Secretary turned Boris defender cheerleader, was widely held to have acquitted himself well during the week on Peston. He must have enjoyed the verbal sparring, because he got up on a Sunday morning to do it all again on Ridge on Sunday.: Johnson campaign gaffe over pollHis only stumble came when he referred to Mr Johnson putting a Cabinet together ldquoafter he wins, which was quickly corrected to ldquo he succeeds.When it came to who would be around the table, Mr Raab preferred to see a ldquowide-ranging Cabinet, albeit one that was disciplined and where the principle of collective responsibility had been restored. So not that wide-ranging then.On The Andrew Marr Show the host was also keen to talk jobs. Not his own, for which, as the BBC annual report showed last week, he is paid between pound,-pound,. He was interested in the job security of David Gauke, the Justice Secretary and prominent Remainer, in any government led by Mr Johnson. ldquoHersquos going to sack you, isnrsquot he  asked the presenter with all the subtlety of a carnival barker.Mr Gauke, whose anti-no deal supporters have been dubbed the Gaukeward Squad, said he would jump before he was pushedbeing part of Team Johnson meant signing up to an October  departure come what may. One down, more to come.Pledges of resignations aside, a calm has settled on the Conservatives, for now at least, following a leadership contest notable for its lack of rancour. That could change on Tuesday when Mr Johnson and Jeremy Hunt take part in the first, live, head to head debate on ITV. For now, the party is more than happy to leave the bad headlines to Labour.: Labour hit by civil war claimsOn the Labour leadershiprsquos calendar it is not Tuesday which has been ringed in red but Wednesday, when a Panorama special, titled ldquoIs Labour Antisemitic , is due to air. As reported in yesterdayrsquos Sunday Times, several former members of Labours staff are said to have torn up the non-disclosure agreementsthey signed in order to speak out on the programme. This has led, in turn, to the issuing of lawyersrsquo letters reminding employees of their obligations.Barry Gardiner, Shadow Secretary of State for International Trade, told Sophy Ridge that the party was not using NDAs to cover up wrongdoing. Taking the attack is the best defence approach, he questioned the balance and impartiality of the Panorama programme. But as the BBC was quick to point out, Mr Gardiner was criticising something he had not yet seen.Panorama is not Labourrsquos only headache. Apart from the continuing muddle over the partyrsquos Brexit position, those shadow ministers on media duty yesterday also had to comment on reports that war was raging between Jeremy Corbynrsquos unelected advisers and those MPs closest to the Labour leader. Mr McDonnell and Diane Abbott were reported to have demanded the sackings of Seamus Milne, head of strategy, and chief of staff Karie Murphy.: Iain Macwhirter on indyrefAsked about this on Marr, Mr McDonnell said he had not called for anyone to be dismissed and any claims to the contrary were ldquomyths and rubbish. Where on Earth could such stories have come from, then  Well-refreshed journalists, said Mr McDonnell, staggering from one summer reception to the next "drinking some of the most nauseating wine ever produced from a grape". A case of sour grapes, then, but only on journalistsrsquo part.As for the state of the Corbyn-McDonnell relationship, it was doing just fine, thanks for asking. "Jeremy and I go back  years, were the closest of friends. Weve minded each others back throughout that period. Yes, well disagree on things, and then well come to an agreement."While he pledged his support to Remain in any future referendum, he defended Mr Corbynrsquos right to dither, or as he put it, to build consensus. That said, Mr McDonnell was conscious of time pressing on. The Shadow Chancellor is in the camp that reckons Prime Minister Johnson could go for a General Election in September.That was not the vision swirling in Labour MP Ian Murrayrsquos crystal ball. Speaking on Sunday Politics Scotland, the former Shadow Scottish Secretary said there would not be a General Election. Moreover, he added, anybody in Labour who wanted one when Labour was languishing at % in the opinion polls ldquois really not on the same planet as the rest of us.All this as television begins a season of programmes celebrating the moon landing. Enjoy the peace and tranquility of the stars: it will be back to Earth with a bump next Sunday for someone.

title: snp-mavericks-suggest-new-route-independence
story: Western Isles MP Angus Brendan MacNeil and Inverclyde councillor Chris McEleny said the SNP winning a majority of seats in a Westminster or Holyrood election would suffice.The pair told The National they hoped to have the idea debated at the SNPrsquos autumn conference, despite Nicola Sturgeon repeatedly insisting that a referendum is essential.The proposals comes after both Tory leadership contenders set their face against granting Holyrood the power to hold Indyrefthey became Prime Minister.:Senior SNP figures in talks with Kremlin-linked bodies on UK tensionsMr Hunt said he would refuse eventhe SNP won an outright majority at the  Holyrood election, while Boris Johnson said he could ldquosee no case for another vote.The plan from Mr MacNeil and Mr McEleny is also a sign of impatience in the Yes movement at the SNPrsquos lack of campaigning on the issue.Their proposal is thatthe UK Government has still not agreed to a Section  order transfer of power by autumn , a majority in the next election would be regarded as a mandate for the Scottish Government to start independence negotiations.Mr McEleny said: ldquoThe people of Scotland have been consistently ignored by the UK Government. We want to hold a referendum to give people the choice between becoming an ordinary independent country or staying part of a UK that consistently imposes on Scotland policies and governments that we reject.ldquoWe need a way to ensure the democratic mandate of Scotland is respected - whether Jeremy Hunt or Boris Johnson like it or not.:SNP lodge an official complaint to Ofcom over Jeremy Vine showTory MSP Maurice Golden said: ldquoThere is no support among Scots for an independence referendum. Now the SNP wants to break up the Union without even asking Scotland first.Scotland in Union campaign chief executive Pamela Nash added: ldquoThis reckless resolution from senior SNP politicians is astounding. Nicola Sturgeon must immediately rule out this irresponsible plan.An SNP spokesman said the party already had a ldquocast-iron mandate to give the people of Scotland the option of becoming independent in a referendum before the  election.He added: ldquoThe First Minister has made clear she believes this should take place toward the latter half of next year. Support for the SNP and for independence are rising.

title: something-shout-lulu-70-studying-acting
story: Now Lulu is hoping to learn how to disguise the familiar voice that has been her ticket to fame, in a new role as an actress.She has revealed she is now studying acting,  years after making her film debut alongside Sir Sidney Poitier in the  drama, To Sir, With Love, when she was just .The decision is said to have been inspired by actor Angus Macfadyen, and comes after she wrote and performed soundtrack music for his new film, Robert The Bruce.Her career swap from singer to actress comes at a time when most people might be considering winding down rather than embarking on new challenges.:The road to discovery: Lulu on fame, friendships and remembering shes ScottishLulu celebrated her th birthday in November. However, the Glasgow-raised singer, whose looks and energy seems to defy time, says she is now working with an acting coach and studying the Meisner technique.Developed by the late American actor and acting teacher Sanford Meisner, it is founded on ldquothe reality of doing and has been taught to or used by movie stars including Jack Nicholson, Diane Keaton, Jeff Goldblum, Robert Duvall, Steve McQueen and Tom Cruise.Lulu appeared last year in Absolutely Fabulous: The MovieShe said: ldquoI love to act and Irsquove actually been studying.ldquoEverything I ever did in my past was just natural but Irsquove been studying Meisner, Irsquove been studying with a great coach and I want to get back into acting.Despite being in her seventh decade and at an age when many actresses complain of finding work offers in decline, Lulu has hinted at already having been given options on acting roles.In an interview with The Heraldrsquos Brian Beacom last week, she said she is considering three acting jobs, including a classic theatre role.She added: ldquoI may be scared sh**less, but Irsquom up for them.Lulu, real name Marie Lawrie, said she had been encouraged to ldquodo more acting by Robert The Bruce star Macfadyen, who asked her to write and perform the closing theme song for the film, which is currently showing in cinemas.She added: ldquoNow I think about it, Angus should have given me a part. Maybe there will be a sequel.Lulu began her singing career at the age of just , appearing with bands in Glasgow clubs to help prop up the family income.She became a household name at the age of  when she recorded her version of the Isley Brothersrsquo song Shout in .The record reached No  in the UK charts.She went on to become the first British female singer to appear live behind the Iron Curtain in  during a tour of Poland with The Hollies, which she followed with her acting debut in To Sir, With Love.The film tackled a series of social and racial issues against the background of a black British Guianan teacher arriving at a tough east London school where he is confronted by groups of unruly and poorly educated teenagers.Lulu has recently completed a tour with Take That, at one point photographing herself standing on a London Underground train wearing sunglasses, baseball cap, flared trousers and towering  shoes as she made her way to the O Arena. She wrote: ldquoOn the way to work at @theolondon tonight... and nobody gave this old bird a seat on the tube, adding the hashtag ldquo#OAP.She would be far from the only established female singer to make the switch from vocalist to actor.Most recently, Lady Gaga received an Oscar nomination for her role in A Star Is Born. However Madonnarsquos venture in acting was less successful, with many of her acting roles receiving poor reviews, with audiences struggling to separate her on-screen persona from that of singing superstar.Lulu made her film debut in  in To Sir, With LoveLulu, who co-writes with her brother Billy Lawrie, said she had been ldquothrilled to be asked to pen music for the Robert The Bruce film.ldquoIrsquove known Angus a long time and when he told me hersquod finally gotdone, I was thrilled but then he said lsquowould you be interested in writing a song rsquo ldquoI said lsquosend me the scriptrsquo, and when we read it my brother and I were blown away. Itrsquos so beautul. There are lines in the song that are in the script ndash itrsquos called The Air Of Freedom.:Lulu at : singer celebrates landmark birthdayldquoIf you have great words, a great script, of course thatrsquos the inspiration, and then he gave us one or two directions of what kind of reaction he wanted from the song, so it came really very quickly.ldquoItrsquos Celtic and this is the first time that wersquove written anything that has a Gaelic flavour to the melody.ldquoIrsquom thrilled to be a part of it. Angus has a tremendous presence on the screen.ldquoAnd at the end, itrsquos just heartbreaking, and then my song comes in over that and it says it all.

title: manmade-superfly-help-feed-worlds-livestock
story: But in a laboratory near Edinburgh, squirming supersize dark brown maggots and cages crammed with tens of thousands of their winged big brothers and sisters are offering a tantalising glimpse into the future of farming.Using selective breeding technology and biotechniques, agriculture food start-up Beta Bug is creating a new strain of manmade lsquosuperflyrsquo designed to help solve some of the problems of feeding the worldrsquos livestock.Eventually, the Beta Bugs lsquobeefed uprsquo black soldier flies and other bugs could provide an efficient protein replacement for soy in farm feed, as well as offering inidual laboratory-tailored insects for specic animal and fish needs.In could result in maggots and insects being adapted to contain high levels of Omega  oils which, once turned into insect-based fishmeal could help boost the oilrsquos presence in farmed salmon, or insects deliberately bred with higher fat content to help meet nutritional needs of cattle and pigs or to be used as biofuels.:Agenda: Cutting-edge research will improve livestock resilienceItrsquos also hoped the technology could also go on to play a key role in helping insect protein food companies scale up farm operations to mass produce bugs for human consumption.According to Beta Bugs director Thomas Farrugia, the dawning of the age of the superbug is simply an evolution of the centuries of selective breeding of animals and plants to maximise agricultural yields.ldquoWe are creating genetically better breeds of bugs, just as better breeds of chicken, pigs, cattle and fish have been produced.ldquoYou can describe it as a lsquosuperflyrsquo, but when you buy chicken in Waitrose, you could also call that a super chicken.ldquoThe high-performance genetics element uses the same approaches as are used in livestock. These are not bugs that glow in the dark.Using a mix of biotechniques and genetic breeding, the start-up develops high-performance strains of black soldier fly and selects traits such as protein content, growth rate, fat composition and temperature tolerance depending on clientsrsquo needs.The animal feed is then made from the highly-optimised fly maggots, helping to avoid environmentally damaging soy which has been blamed for deforestation and high carbon footprint.The black soldier fly larvae are particularly effective, thanks to an apparently insatiable appetite and astonishing ability to turn almost any kind of organic waste ndash from agricultural leftovers to faeces ndash into high-quality protein, helping to solve two environmental issues at once.While the fly larvae are currently on the agricultural menu, the start-up could also move into developing more efficient ieties of mealworms and crickets for human consumption, making the protein source more affordable.In the case of mealworms, laboratory adaption could help provide an alternative to environmentally devastating palm oil production ndash mealworms have been found to have healthy fatty acid properties similar to palm oil, but with the potential for faster and more efficient production.According to Farrugia, a key benefit of super insect-based animal feeds and fishmeal is that it has the potential to be produced in Scotland ndash avoiding the need to important soy-based feeds mainly from America.Meanwhile, there could also be spin-off benefits for healthier farmed products. ldquoFor example, more salmon are being farmed, and therersquos a need for more fishmeal, he adds. ldquoBut the limit for fishmeal is capped so each fish gets less, which means it takes in less Omega .ldquoWe now need to eat twice the amount of salmon now as we did  years ago to get the same Omega . So, wersquore looking at ways of adding Omega  to the insect product.The start-up, based at Edinburgh Universityrsquos Roslin Innovation Centre, is one of  businesses which was last year selected as part of the Scottish Governmentrsquos poundm challenge fund, Unlocking Ambition.Half were established businesses which have spent the past year being guided by mentors linked to Scottish Enterprise, while the remaining  young start-ups, including Beta Bugs, were introduced to the Royal Society of Edinburghrsquos Unlocking Ambition Enterprise Fellowship programme.:Mad cow disease confirmed on Scottish farmAmong them is a revolutionary robotic lawnmower business, which has introduced ground-breaking mapping technology to enable machines to work across large areas of land, such as golf courses and parks.Joan Kangro, the founder of Kingdom Technologies Ltd., says the robotic lawnmowers have been designed with multiple sensors and cameras to enable them to operate safely in public spaces.ldquoOther robot lawnmowers use reactive safety measures, sothey bump into an obstruction they will go in a new direction. But studies have shown thatrsquos not safe around children and pets, he says.ldquoOur robot sees when someone comes into close proximity and stops before it hits the object.The large terrain robotic lawnmowers are also designed to cut the lawnrsquos edges and close to obstacles ndash removing the need to trim edges of flower beds ndash and to operate using mapping technology, removing the need for boundary cables.Other businesses included in the RSE Fellowship include CogniCare, which uses machine learning to offer personalised support to people affected by dementia, Fodilicious which provides premium, lsquofree-fromrsquo convenience foods including low FODMAP, gluten-free and vegan, and ALICAS which gts bespoke clothing parcels to women in clothing crisis.Professor Dame Anne Glover, RSE President said: ldquoScotland has a global reputation for innovation, and we need to maintain that entrepreneurial spirit. Itrsquos vital that we have a sustainable approach to supporting start-ups that create high-quality jobs, boost the Scottish economy and change lives through new ideas.ldquoThe RSErsquos Unlocking Ambition Enterprise Fellowship was designed with those goals in mind and participants have grasped the opportunity., with some fantastic results after just  months. Time, money, and expert advice and guidance are key to turning a bright idea into a viable business with long-term potential and our programme has offered all of these to early-stage businesses with masses of potential.ldquoThese companies are the employers of tomorrow, innovating for the future, and we have helped them to take huge strides forward in their growth journey towards being Scotlandrsquos business success stories.

title: love-island-goes-dumb---scotland-england-place
story: Some say shows such as The Only Way is Essex, Big Brother and Geordie Shore are createthe impression that being dumb is the route to wealth and riches.Eighteen years ago, when Brian Dowling became winner of the second series of Big Brother, the runner-up Welsh hairdresser Helen Adams became known for her "Helen-isms" such as: "Is there chicken in chickpeas "This years Love Island has just thrownup even more cringeworthy conversations leaving Scots viewers indisbelief.Belle Hassan, a -year-old make-up artist from Kent was the focus of the incredulity after pairing up with -year-old Scots gym owner Anton Danyluk.:Neil Mackay: Its time the tiger of reality TV was tamedShe asked him: "Is Scotland and England the same place, like the same country "Mr Danyluklooked confused when he said: "What  Is Scotland and England the same country ""Its the same thing isnt it," said the girl he is coupled up within the Mallorca villa that Love Island is set.The Scot replied: "Its in Britain."The fitness fanthen turned to some of the other male contestants and said: "Did you hear this chat  She says is Scotland and England the same place."Ms Hassan, who is the daughter of actor Tamer Hassan, who has appearances in the No Way Out movie as TV shows EastEnders, Hotel Babylon, The Bill and Casualty added: "They are though, theyre the same... they are not, like disconnected."Before that Ms Hassan explained to some of the other girls at the villa that she managed to clear up that "Edinburgh is actually in Scotland last night".Joanna Chimonides replied: "Is it ":The Big Read: what Love Island really says about the world we live inMs Hassan stressed: "Seriously!""I didnt know, oh my god," said Ms Chimondies."After revealing her findings about Scotlands capital Ms Hassan whose commentary was seen on the ITV shows Unseen Bits show added: "Dublin is in Ireland. Did you know that "Giving more ammunition to the Love Island critics, Ms Chimondes replied: "I didnrsquot knowhellipoh my god...is Italy in Rome or Rome in Italy "Model Jourdan Rianeconfirmed to the pair that Rome is in fact the capital of Italy.Ms Hassan then goes on to ask: "Is Barcelona in Rome "Ms Riane replies: "Barcelona is in Italy" with a confused Ms Hassan responding: "I thought it was Spanish."Jo Heywood, head of Heathfield School in Ascot, Berkshire, said four years ago that she was "deeply concerned about the dumbing down of culture in the UK".She singled out TOWIEs Joey Essex, who cannot tell the time and is capitalising on his reputation for being dense as well as former cast member, Mark Wright, for particular criticism.In a blog published on her schools website, Mrs Heywood, said: "At first, reality TV may have seemed ironic ndash a TV experiment where we peered in at others lives but now it has taken on a le of its own and some of its stars reflect the education system they have been brought up in."Some children and teenagers see them as role models whose behaviour they wish to emulate and whose lives they wish to emulate."

title: auld-reekie-streets-ahead-mission-slash-car-fumes
story: And in Edinburgh, the last Open Streets event until October was enjoyed by thousands in the heart of the Capital.The Open Streets concept began in America in , aiming to improve the quality of le for people by drawing residents and visitors together, clearing the streets of traffic and staging events, from street parties to festivals, to make the most of the open roads and help clean-up air quality.The cityrsquos third Open Streets saw a host of events and activities take place, including a focus on enjoying Oor Wulliersquos Big Bucket Trail, as well as free tours around Edinburghrsquos historic Old Town, courtesy of Edinburgh Festival Voluntary Guided Walks.:Rab McNeil: Lets get back to having a high old time in our town centresBetween North Bridge and St Maryrsquos Street, there were street games, including Connect , chess and badminton, while Literary Walking Tours set off from the Scottish Storytelling Centre. There were also free yoga sessions on the High Street.Social media users lit up Twitter and Facebook with images of the novelty of Edinburghrsquos car-free routes.On Twitter, Gary Sloan posted an image of a quiet Victoria Street, with pedestrians meandering on the actual road, saying: ldquoOpen Streets in Edinburgh today. No traffic.Friends of the EarthScotland Tweeted: ldquoOpen Streets is a great initiative which will improve air quality for one day, on the Royal Mile. Take two mins to tell the Council everyone in Edinburgh deserves clean air.#OpenStreets is a great initiative which will improve air quality for one day, on the Royal Mile. Take  mins to tell the Council everyone in Edinburgh deserves clean air. https:t.co xoEuvmtTjjAnd Aisha Moohan said on Facebook: Itrsquos great for this weekend. At least the people are free to roam around on Edinburghrsquos streets. Fun-filled activities and great weather.Not everyone was thrilled, though, with some social media users expressing dismay. Imy Saeed said: ldquoOh great this nonsense again.The city introduced the Open Streets as a pilot programme in May to create a ldquopeople friendly route around the Old Town, saying it aimed to ldquopromote a healthy, active, inclusive city to celebrate and add to the culture of the city to contribute to the cityrsquos economy and to inform future initiatives.:Ann Fotheringham: On climate change, young people and standing up for what you believe inEdinburgh was the first city in the UK to join the movement, which offers the opportunity to measure the impact of reducing traffic.Councillor Lesley Macinnes, Transport and Environment Convener, said then: ldquoWersquove seen how successful many similar schemes internationally have proved by encouraging active travel, improving air quality and creating a safer, more relaxed atmosphere.ldquoClimate change is a real threat to society. Itrsquos clear that we have to act, and Open Streets is undoubtedly a step in the right direction.In Paris, where car-free Sundays see traffic banned from key areas of the city ndash including the Champs-Elysees from am to pm ndash there is a  per cent drop in harmful exhaust emissions during this period, according to air-quality monitoring network, Airpart.In Scotland, figures show around , early deaths are caused every year because of polluted air, which has been linked to heart disease and lung problems, including asthma.Figures from FoE Scotland, released in January, revealed air quality on Scotlandrsquos most polluted street deteriorated further in the previous year.The two measures of air pollution are nitrogen dioxide and particulate matter , both caused by fossil-fuel engines.And nitrogen dioxide levels on Hope Street in Glasgow averaged  micrograms per cubic metrein  compared with  in , while Queensferry Road in Edinburgh was second on the list for nitrogen oxide and it also became the most-polluted street for PM.On December , Glasgow city centre became Scotlandrsquos first Low Emission Zone , which discourages certain types of vehicles from entering a specied zone and sets an environmental limit on certain road spaces, allowing access to only the cleanest vehicles.LEZs were first introduced in Sweden in  and there are now more than  such zones across  European countries, either in operation or planned.In , the Programme for Government committed to introducing LEZs in Scotlandrsquos four biggest cities between  and , and then into all other local authority areas deemed to have poor quality air caused by pollution by . The zones were also included in the new TransportBill, introduced in Parliament on June  last year, which set the national framework for Scottish local authorities to introduce and enforce the zones.Aberdeen and Dundee are also due to create zones by the end of next year, while Edinburghrsquos newly proposed zone is expected to be in place by the end of . The next Open Streets in Edinburgh is due to take place on October .

title: highs-lows-island-practice
story: an island practiceHighs and lows of Dr Alexander had arrived with his family some months earlier and had slowly eased into the rhythms of island le, and learning to appreciate just how central the church, the eight-pupil school and the GPrsquos surgery were to the inhabitants.Now, here he is, relaxing as best he can from the stresses of being on call round the clock, allowing himself to be lulled by the wind and the waves.He is pleased to glimpse oystercatchers the plaintive sound of peewits reminds him irresistibly of his childhood in the Pentland Hills.The water, he writes, is an acrylic mix of blues and greens. ldquoThe air, he continues, ldquobreathes in time with me as it ebbs and flows through the coarse heather stalks. This is close to where the heart gives out. .But then a Loganair plane passes noisily overhead, and real le intrudes, as it must: on board are two policemen, come to investigate the disappearance of Ivan, a withdrawn local man who has done some work for Dr Alexander. Ivan is later found dead, from natural causes.Dr Alexander had given up his Glasgow practice for ious reasons and, together with his we Maggie, a former anaesthetist, their four boysand their gaggle of pets , had made the long journey to Eday, where he had been appointed as the local GP. The island lies off the Orkney mainland, watched over by Westray, Sanday, Stronsay and Rousay.He wasnrsquot bowled over by the GPrsquos house and surgery when he first encountered them, however. The house was largely dilapidated, with a grubby bathroom the surgery was equally desolate, with a torn examination couch and a computer and keyboard covered in dust.It says much for him that he didnrsquot have an immediate change of heart andto Glasgow and their ldquobeautul west end home. But remain he did.One of the very first patient files he opened was a poignant one: an elderly lady, Agnes ndash Nessie, who was born in , and who lived almost her entire le on Eday, moving only briefly to mainland Orkney, after the Great War. Her medical history and, indeed, her le history were contained in that file.Amidst descriptions of island le, andof the islanders themselves, a key moment in the book occurs when Maggie, newly pregnant, has to be rushed to hospital in Aberdeen after serious complications arise, forcing Dr Alexander to look after their four sons while continuing to see to his many patients.These and other events happened exactly  years ago. The good doctor retired in  and now, aged , lives on another island, Bute. But in this -page book, which details his first year as Edayrsquos GP, they are as fresh asthey happened yesterday.ldquoI suppose it did surprise me, that I could remember so many details, he says. ldquoWhen I started out on the book, the heart of the story was Maggie having to go away. Irsquod been having an email exchange with my agent Laura [Macdougall, of United Agents], who had been looking for somebody who had done the kind of job that I had done. She asked me, what could I write ldquoI thought the best place to start was the really emotional aspects, and then seeI can build from there. It was remarkable what I could remember once you put yourself back into the place.ldquoIt was quite an emotional experience, a powerful one, to write about Eday after a gap of  years, to unwrap things you hadnrsquot thought of.ldquoOne of the boys said it was fascinating to read about their le from somebody rsquos perspective. They think, lsquooh, thatrsquos how dad saw us at that timersquo, and it made me think about how I responded to them as kids.ldquoObviously, in the book there are regrets and there are achievements, nice things as well, but it was quite testing at times, just to write some of the simplest things.Dr Alexander and his family remained on Eday until . They went to Stromness, where he served as one of the GPs, and eventually, on Kirkwall, he became the medical director at Orkney Health Board after that, he was Associate Medical Director at NHS  before going full circle and working at his local GP practice on Bute.His book certainly has a strong sense of place. ldquoThatrsquos what struck me most particularly about the physical location, because you can just see so many things on it. One thing I didnrsquot mention in the book was the Stone of Setter, which is right in the middle of Eday and is one of the tallest standing stones in Orkney. These things are all over the place. You canrsquot escape the fact that there was a Neolithic presence. You canrsquot escape the geology, because it keeps erupting in front of you. It really is quite a remarkable place.ldquoIrsquove gone back regularly to Orkney, managing almost annually, but have only once been back to Eday since we left. When Maggie and I last went, we had a look-round and tried to find folks, and chat to them. That was probably the hardest part, not being able to find them, because obviously a lot of them have died, or moved off the island.ldquoWe subsequently tracked down a couple of people, though. Some of the kids are still there: we were able to meet the ones who had been at school with our kids, but most of the folk who created that environment, which almost had a s feel to it, most of them have moved on.Had Eday changed much from the time when he was the sole local GP  ldquoPhysically, it doesnrsquot look as though it has changed much, he says. ldquoMaybe therersquos a little less obvious crofting, with its stacks, its stacks of hay and barley and peat ... that seemed to have disappeared a bit, from what I could see.Can he envisage having been Edayrsquos GP for the last  years  ldquoThe challenge, he says, ldquowould have been keeping up to date. That would have been the real issue, Whereas now, [no GP] really stays in the one place exclusively, so they can get as wide a training as possible.For a first-time writer, he has done an excellent job with his account. In reference to that passage where he is enjoying nature just before he sees the Loganair plane coming in to land, he says: ldquoI wanted to try to capture the feel of the peace,you like, of the place, but also the speed which with reality can intrude.ldquoYou had to get used to that. If you couldnrsquot live with that, then you had to move on, you had to go back to at least a town environment, where somebody  could take over and be on call.ldquoI loved it, but I was brought up with it ndash we were used to being on our own we were used to seeing the road blocked with snow, and not fussing.Close to Where the Heart Gives Out: A Year in the Le of an Orkney Doctorhardback , Michael OrsquoMara Books.

title: mussels-stressed-sea-noise-scottish-research-suggests
story: Scientists said that while this was not ldquoimmediately dangerous for the creatures, it could impact on growth and may even help explain a decline in mussel banks in some areas of the UK.Previous studies have looked at how noise affects larger marine creatures, such as whales and dolphins.Now a team of marine scientists from Napier University and Heriot Watt University, both in Edinburgh, have looked at the impact on mussels.Despite the molluscs not having ears, the researchers found they can detect changing sound levels in their environment.The scientists collected mussels from the shore at Musselburgh, outside Edinburgh, and tested their response to noise in a lab at the St Abbs Marine Station near Eyemouth ndash a charity dedicated to marine science, conservation and education.Karen Diele, from Edinburgh Napier University, the co-director of research at the marine station, said: ldquoThe blue mussel is an extremely important invertebrate in the UK: it is commercially valuable and it plays an essential ecological role as a reef builder and a filter-feeder that keeps the water clean.Read more:New plea for Scotlands at-risk pearl mussel as bid to stop illegal fishing faltersShe added: ldquoMussels donrsquot have ears but they can detect changing sound levels in their environment.ldquoWe recorded and played the sound of a shiprsquos motor to a sample of blue mussels in a controlled setting, and measured biochemical and behavioural changes in the mussels.ldquoFor the first time in a marine species, we detected noise-induced changes in DNA integrity, indicating an underlying source of stress.Matt Wale, also from Edinburgh Napier University, told how the mussels that had been exposed to noise consumed % less oxygen ndash adding this would lead to increased energy use and potentially slower growth.He continued: ldquoThe filtration rate, or how much algae they consume, decreased by over % and there was a % increase in valve gape, which means the mussels are spending more time vulnerable to predators.Another member of the team, Mark Hartl from Heriot-Watt University, stated: ldquoGiven the wide distribution of mussels in areas where they may be exposed to noise, the impact of noise does not appear to be fatal or immediately dangerous for mussels.Read more:Climate change: Scottish shellfish threatened by Japanese invadersldquoHowever, this doesnrsquot mean it isnrsquot having a long-term effect on mussel populations in high noise areas, it could be affecting their growth, reproductivity and may help explain the decline of mussel banks in some areas of the UK.He added: ldquoItrsquos important that we understand how noise is stressing mussels in environmental risk assessments so that we can ensure environmental policy and regulation is effective.The research was supported with funding from the Marine Alliance for Science and Technology for Scotland.The team is also looking at how Norway lobsters, squid and native oysters respond to underwater noise.

title: may-acknowledge-debt-gratitude-military-farewell-defence-speech
story: Three Chinook transport helicopters and their crews have been based in the African country since July last year in support of French operations against extremists.The Prime Minister will announce a six-month extension to the operation as she delivers her final military speech before leaving office later this month.She will visit the UKrsquos Permanent Joint Headquartersand Natorsquos maritime headquarters in Northwood, north-west London, to thank the military for their efforts under her premiership.Mrs May is expected to say: ldquoThere is no greater responsibility as Prime Minister than ensuring the safety and security of our people.ldquoAnd doing so is not something any Prime Minister can achieve without you ndash the brave men and women of our armed forces.ldquoYou are not just a part of British le ndash you are the guarantors of British le. The foundation of our freedom. The protectors of our democracy. And for that, we owe you a debt of gratitude.She will stress the continued importance of Nato in dealing with the international threats facing the UK.US President Donald Trumprsquos commitment to the alliance has been questioned and he has repeatedly challenged the European members to spend more on their own defence.But Mrs May insisted Nato was every bit as relevant now as when it was set up.ldquoWhile the threats we face may y and evolve, the founding principles of Nato ndash that we are mightier together than alone and that an attack on one is an attack on all ndash remain every bit as important and relevant today as they were in , she will say.ldquoTerrorists, people traffickers, international criminals and state and non-state aggressors do not respect national boundaries, and nor should our response to the threats they pose.Mrs Mayrsquos speech is expected to highlight her visit to Iraq in , where she met troops involved in training local forces.And she will also praise the armed forces for their ldquoround the clock role in decontaminating Salisbury after the nerve agent attack on Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia in March .

title: hope-500-jobs-lidl-plans-12-new-scottish-stores
story: The proposals include facelts for eight existing stores.The supermarket chain currently has  Scottish stores and plans to open its th next year.Dumbarton, Dundee, East Kilbride, Cowdenbeath and Larkhall, where construction is already underway, are among the places which will see new outlets.The news follows the recent opening of a Lidl in Paisley.As part of its regeneration programme, Lidl will be enhancing a number of its existing stores, either through extensions or relocations to bigger sites, in order to cater for growing demand in areas that the supermarket already serves. This includes the relocation of its Alloa and Bathgate stores, which have served their local communities since  and  respectively.Ross Millar, Lidlrsquos Regional Director for Scotland, said: ldquoSince opening our very first store in Scotland  years ago, wersquove opened our doors to towns and cities across the country, employing more than , people."Wersquore incredibly excited by our ambitious growth plans, and in particular the opening of our th store next year, which reinforces our commitment to creating new jobs and providing communities with quality produce at prices that are affordable for everyone.In April, Lidl welcomed local politicians to the construction site of its new warehouse in Eurocentral, which is set to be fully operational by November, and which will support the expansion plans.The , sqm distribution centre will be Lidlrsquos largest in Great Britain when it opens, and will replace its existing Scottish warehouse in Livingston, helping to support the supermarketrsquos future growth across Scotland.The supermarket claims to be "passionate" about sourcing local produce, and currently stocks over  products from over  suppliers across Scotland, ranging from quality fruit and vegetables, to dairy and bakery lines.

title: aberdeenshire dancers head to holyrood
story: A collection of Aberdeenshire#s finest Highland Dancers are heading to the Scottish Parliament to help celebrate its th Anniversary.The dancers will help entertain guests in a fun-filled day at Holyrood on Saturday, June .A whole host of activities will take place on the day including live music and dance, retro games, and a rare opportunity to go behind the scenes of the Parliament and sit in the Presiding Officer’s seat.Sessions will be hosted on ‘The Future of Scotland’ where guests can remotely control robots of the future, experience D Holograms, or discuss their aspirations for Scotland for the next  years.There will also be  debates, including a Festival of Politics session which discusses the concept of ‘Happiness’.Looking ahead to the event, the Parliament’s Presiding Officer, the Rt Hon Ken Macintosh MSP said: “Our focus has always been for this Parliament to be open and accessible for all and what better opportunity to open our doors than for our th Anniversary celebrations.“There truly is something for everyone as we celebrate our birthday and play host to the best of Scottish culture."data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.mearnsleader webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The asset transfer bid for the mill is facing refusal"  Mill asset transfer facing refusal viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "MEAR | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "MEAR | Article Teaser"

story: Two cyclists will fly the flag for Inverurie at its Pyrenean twin town this month during the world#s most gruelling and famous bike race.Pete Lowson, founder and chair of the Inverurie Cycling Club “Team Ecosse Northboats” , and club member, Lucy Ritchie, will be inBagneres-de-Bigorre, as it celebrates the arrival of the th stage of the annual Tour de France cycle race on July .Pete is flying to France especially to share in the area’s biggest day of  but Lucy’s visit the day before will be all-too brief.Lucy will be almost half-way through taking part in one of the toughest cycle challenges on the planet, to raise awareness of gender equality in cycling.
